quest_title: In a meter bridge with a standard resistance of 5? in the left gap, the ratio of balancing heights on the meter resistance is 2:3. The unknown resistance is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{X}{Y}=\cfrac{l_{1}}{l_{2}}\)

\(Y=\cfrac{l_{1}}{l_{2}} \times X=\cfrac{3}{2} \times 5=7.5 \Omega\)

quest_title: The magnetic moment of a magnet is 0.1 Am\({}^{2}\) and force acting on each pole in a uniform magnetic flux density of 0.36 gauss is 1.224 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-4}\) N. The distance between the poles of the magnet is
explanation_txt:
We know that \(F = mB\)

\(\therefore \, m = \cfrac{F}{B} = \cfrac{1.224 \times 10^{-4}}{0.36 \times 10^{-4}} = 4 \, \text{Am} \)

\( \therefore M = m \times 2l \)

or, \( 2l = \cfrac{M}{m} = \cfrac{0.1}{4} = 2.5 \, \text{cm} \)

quest_title: 2.8 of iron displaces 3.2g of copper from a solution of copper sulphate. If the equivalent mass of iron is 28, the equivalent mass of copper will be:
explanation_txt:
2.8 g of iron displaces 3.2 g of copper.

28 g of iron displaces 32 g of copper.

\(\therefore\) Equivalent mass of copper = 32
question_plain_title: 2.8 of iron displaces 3.2g of copper from a solution of copper sulphate. If the equivalent mass of iron is 28, the equivalent mass of copper will be:

28 g of iron displaces 32 g of copper.

Equivalent mass of copper = 32

quest_title: \(A \cap (A \cup B)\) = ?
explanation_txt:
It is always nice to tackle such questions with Venn-diagrams. The intersection of shaed regions ( because there is \(\cap\) in between \(A\) and \(A\cup B\) ) in given Venn-diagram shows why the answer is \(A\).

Other way is to suppose some random sets as \(A\) and \(B\) like:

\(A=\{1,2,3\} \\ B =\{a,b\}\)

So, \(A\cup B = \{a,b,1,2,3\}\)

Finally, \(A\cap (A\cup B) = \{1,2,3\} = A\)

quest_title: What is meant by the ionization energy of an element?
ans1_txt: It is the energy relased when an electron is added to an atom of the element
ans2_txt: It is the energy required to remove the outermost electron of an atom of the element.
ans3_txt: It is equal to magnitude but opposite in size to the electronegativity of the element
ans4_txt: It is the same as the electron affinity of the element
explanation_txt: In physics and chemistry, ionization energy or ionisation energy, denoted Eᵢ, is the minimum amount of energy required to remove the most loosely bound electron, the valence electron, of an isolated neutral gaseous atom or molecule. (Wikipedia)
question_plain_title: What is meant by the ionization energy of an element?
explanation_plain_text: In physics and chemistry, ionization energy or ionisation energy, denoted Eᵢ, is the minimum amount of energy required to remove the most loosely bound electron, the valence electron, of an isolated neutral gaseous atom or molecule. (Wikipedia)
ans1_plain_text: It is the energy relased when an electron is added to an atom of the element
ans2_plain_text: It is the energy required to remove the outermost electron of an atom of the element.
ans3_plain_text: It is equal to magnitude but opposite in size to the electronegativity of the element
ans4_plain_text: It is the same as the electron affinity of the element

quest_title: Which type of compounds show high melting and boiling points ?

 \(\text{E\(^{ 0}\)}\) cell = - 1.02 v , the reaction.

quest_title: If \(A = \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { \cos \alpha } & { - \sin \alpha } \\ { \sin \alpha } & { \cos \alpha } \end{array} \right]\) and \(B = \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { \cos \beta } & { - \sin \beta } \\ { \sin \beta } & { \cos \beta } \end{array} \right]\), then the correct relation is

\( A B = \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { \cos \alpha } & { - \sin \alpha } \\ { \sin \alpha } & { \cos \alpha } \end{array} \right] \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { \cos \beta } & { - \sin \beta } \\ { \sin \beta } & { \cos \beta } \end{array} \right] \\ = \left[ \begin{array} { c c } { \cos ( \alpha + \beta ) } & { - \sin ( \alpha + \beta ) } \\ { \sin ( \alpha + \beta ) } & { \cos ( \alpha + \beta ) } \end{array} \right] \\ =BA \)

(Verify for BA)

quest_title: If in a triangle \(A B C \) right angled at \(B , s - a = 3 , s - c = 2\), \(s - a = 3 , s - c = 2 \) then the values of a and c are respectively:
explanation_txt:
\( s - a = 3 \Rightarrow b + c - a = 6 \dots (i) \)

\( s - a = 3 \Rightarrow b + c - a = 6 \dots (ii) \)

Adding these two equations, we get \(b=5\)

Since \(B\) is a right angle,

\(\therefore b ^ { 2 } = a ^ { 2 } + c ^ { 2 } \Rightarrow a ^ { 2 } + c ^ { 2 } = 25 \dots (iii) \)

Solving we get, \(a=3, b=4 \)

quest_title: The equation of the plane through the origin containing the line \(\cfrac{x-1}{5} =\cfrac{y-2}{4} =\cfrac{z-3}{5} \) is
explanation_txt:
Let the plane be \( Ax + By +Cz = 0 \) [D = 0 as the plane passes through origin]

But, as the plane contains the line with dr's 5,4,5, the dr's of its normal should satisfy:

\[ 5A + 4B + 5C = 0 \quad \dots (i) \]

Also, the plane should contain \( (1,2,3) \), as it lies on the line.

So,

\[ A + 2B + 3C = 0 \quad \dots (ii) \]

From (i) and (ii),

\[ \cfrac{A}{2} = \cfrac{B}{-10} = \cfrac{C}{6} \\ \Rightarrow A = \cfrac{B}{-5} = \cfrac{C}{3} \]

So, the plane is \( x - 5y + 3z = 0 \)

quest_title: The percentage errors in the measurement of mass and speed are 2% and 3% respectively. How much will be the maximum error in the estimation of the kinetic energy obtained by measuring mass and speed
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \therefore E = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } m v ^ { 2 } } \\ { \therefore \% \text { Error in K.E. } } \\ { = \% \text { error in mass } + 2 \times \% \text { error in velocity } } \\ { = 2 + 2 \times 3 = 8 \% } \end{array}\)

quest_title: A body sliding on a smooth inclined plane requires 4 seconds to reach the bottom starting from rest at top. The time taken by it to cover one fourth of distance is
explanation_txt:
\(I=\cfrac{1}{2} a t^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} a \times 4^{2}=8 a\)

Again,

\(\begin{aligned} \cfrac{l}{4} &=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{at}^{\prime 2} \\ \text { or, } \mathrm{t}^{\prime} &=\sqrt{\cfrac{l}{2 \mathrm{a}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{8 \mathrm{a}}{2 \mathrm{a}}}=2 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The weight of a man on the surface of earth is 90kg weight. The mass of mass is 1/9 \({}^{th}\) that of the earth and radius is half that of the earth then weight of man on mars will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{mg}=90\)
\(\mathrm{mg}^{\prime}=\cfrac{G M m^{\prime}}{R^{2}}=\cfrac{G M m \times 4}{9 R^{2}}\)

\(\qquad=\cfrac{4}{9} m g=\cfrac{4}{9} \times 90=40 \, \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{wt}\)

quest_title: A double convex thin lens made of glass of refractive index 1.6 has radius of curvature 15cm each. The focal length of this lens when immersed in a fluid of refractive index 1.63 is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{m}}}=\left(\cfrac{\mu_{\mathrm{g}}}{\mu_{l}}-1\right)\left(\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{R}_{2}}\right)=\left(\cfrac{1.6}{1.63}-1\right) \cfrac{2}{15}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{m}}=-407.5 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: Which does not obey octet rule?
explanation_txt:
1. CO contains two covalent bonds and one coordinate covalent bond. C and O end up having 8 electrons each
  2. In NO, N after receiving 2 electrons from O, has 7 electrons, thus octet is not fulfilled
  3. In, O2 each O atom has 8 electrons

  3. In, O2 each O atom has 8 electrons

quest_title: If a source emitting waves of frequency 'f' moves towards an observer with velocity V/3 and observer moves away from the source with velocity v/4, the apparent frequency is heard by the observer will be (v=velocity of sound)
explanation_txt:
Here, some is approaching and observer is receding from it.

Apparent frequency is given by:

\(\mathrm{f}^{\prime}=\left(\cfrac{v-v_{0}}{v-v_{\mathrm{s}}}\right) \times \mathrm{f}=\left(\cfrac{v-v / 4}{v-v / 3}\right) \times \mathrm{f}=\cfrac{9}{8} \mathrm{f}\)

quest_title: A compound contains C=90% and H = 10%. Empirical formula of the compound is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array} { l l l } { \text { Elements } } & { \text { No. of Moles } } & { \text { Simple ratio } } \\ { C = 90 \% } & { 90 / 12 = 7.5 } & { 7.5 / 7.5 = 1 \times 3 = 3 } \\ { H = 10 \% } & { 10 / 1 = 10 } & { 10 / 7.5 = 1.33 \times 3 = 4 } \end{array}\)

\(\therefore \text { Empirical formula } = C _ { 3 } H _ { 4 }\)

quest_title:
Consider the electronic configurations of the elements x, y and z as;  
 \(\mathrm{x}: 1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{6} 3 \mathrm{s}^{1} \quad \mathrm{y}: 1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{6} 3 \mathrm{s}^{2} \quad \mathrm{z}: 1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{6}\)
ans1_txt: Atomic radius of y is greater than that of x
ans2_txt: first ionization energy of x is greater than that of y
ans3_txt: The electron affinity of z is very large
ans4_txt: The \(2^{nd}\) ionization energy of y is less than that of x
explanation_txt:
After losing 1 electrons x attains stable Neon configuration so its ionization energy increases rapidly.

But in case of y the ionization energy is almost the same after losing a electron.

quest_title: The function \( f ( x ) = \sin \left( \log \left( x + \sqrt { x ^ { 2 } + 1 } \right) \right) \) is
explanation_txt:
Let \( g(x) = \log ( x + \sqrt{x^2+1}) \)

So, \( g(-x) = \log ( -x + \sqrt{x^2 + 1} ) = \log \left( \left( \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } - x \right) \cfrac { \left( \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } + x \right) } { \left( \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } + x \right) } \right)=\log \left[ \cfrac { 1 } { \left( x + \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } \right) } \right] = - \log \left( x + \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } \right) \)

Hence \( f(-x) = \sin (g (-x)) = - \sin \left[ \log \left( x + \sqrt { 1 + x ^ { 2 } } \right) \right] \)

Since \( f(-x) =-f(x) \) the function is odd.

NOTE:

  • \( \log ( x + \sqrt{x^2+1} ) = \sinh ^ {-1} x \)
  • \( \log ( x + \sqrt{x^2-1} ) = \cosh ^ {-1} x \)

Since \( \sinh^{-1} (-x) = - \sinh^{-1} x \) and \( \sin(-x) = - \sin x \) it is easy to see why the function is odd.

quest_title: If \(z\) is a complex number such that \(z ^ { 2 } = ( \overline { z } ) ^ { 2 }\) then
ans3_txt: either z is purely real or purely imaginary
explanation_txt:
Let \(z = x + i y\), then its conjugate \(\overline { z } = x - i y\)

Given that \(z ^ { 2 } = ( \overline { z } ) ^ { 2 }\)

\(\Rightarrow x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } + 2 i x y = x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } - 2 i x y \Rightarrow 4 i x y = 0\)

So, \(x=0\) or \(y=0\).

\(=\cfrac{1}{x}\)

quest_title: A block of mass 50 kg can slide on a rough horizontal surface. The coefficient of friction between block and surface is 0.6. The least force of pull acting at an angle of 30\(^{\circ}\) to vertical which cause the block to just slide is
explanation_txt:
\(F \sin \theta=\mu R\)

\(F \sin 30=\mu(m g-F \cos \theta)\)
or, \(F=\cfrac{\mu m g}{\sin \theta+\mu \cos \theta}\)

\(\qquad=\cfrac{0.6 \times 50 \times g}{\sin 30+0.6 \times \cos 30}=29.4 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{wt}\)

quest_title: A person can see the object clearly from 15cm to 100cm from eye. The range of vision whil wearing the spectacle of -0.8D is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{P}=-0.8 \mathrm{D}\)

\(\mathrm{P}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{1}{-0.8} \times 100=-125 \mathrm{cm}\)

For near object:

\(\mathrm{u}=? \mathrm{v}=-15 \mathrm{cm} \quad \mathrm{f}=-125 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{u}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fv}}{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{(-125)(-15)}{-15+125}=17 \mathrm{cm}\)

for distant object

\(\mathrm{u}=? \quad \mathrm{v}=-100 \mathrm{cm}, \quad \mathrm{f}=-125 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{u}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fv}}{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{(-125)(-100)}{-15+125}=500 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\therefore\) Range \(=17 \mathrm{cm}\) to 500 \(\mathrm{cm}\)

explanation_txt:
Some amount of mass is converted to huge amount of energy during fusion. So, the total mass of products is always less than the total mass of reactants.

From Einstein's mass energy relation,

\(E=\Delta mc^{2}\)
